title: High Urban Slum Population
description: In 2016, 94.2% of South Sudan's urban population lived in slums, indicating significant urban poverty and inadequate housing conditions.

title: Excessive Government Expenditure
description: In 2022, South Sudan's primary government expenditures were 168.04% of the original approved budget, highlighting fiscal challenges.

title: High Rate of Over-Age Students
description: In 2015, 50.2% of male and 48.6% of total primary school enrollments were over-age, indicating educational delays.

title: Significant School Dropout Rates
description: In 2015, 63.0% of children of primary school age were out of school, reflecting educational access issues.

title: High Pupil-Teacher Ratio in Secondary Schools
description: In 2015, the pupil-teacher ratio in lower secondary schools was 46.7, suggesting overcrowded classrooms.

title: High Neonatal Mortality Rate
description: In 2023, South Sudan had a neonatal mortality rate of 40.2 per 1,000 live births, indicating healthcare challenges for newborns.

title: Widespread Poverty
description: In 2016, 82.3% of the population lived below the national poverty line, highlighting widespread economic hardship.

title: Severe Food Insecurity
description: In 2022, 63.2% of the population experienced severe food insecurity, reflecting critical food supply issues.

title: High Infant Mortality Rates
description: In 2023, the infant mortality rate was 72.6 per 1,000 live births, with male infants at 78.3 and female infants at 66.8, indicating severe health challenges.

title: Youthful Population
description: In 2023, 12.3% of the female and 12.9% of the male population were aged 15-19, indicating a youthful demographic.

title: Minimal Fertilizer Usage
description: In 2022, South Sudan had the lowest fertilizer consumption globally, with only 0.000555 kilograms per hectare of arable land.

title: Low Control of Corruption
description: In 2023, South Sudan's control of corruption estimate was -1.97, indicating significant challenges in governance and transparency.

title: Limited Urban Electricity Access
description: Only 19.1% of South Sudan's urban population had access to electricity in 2023, highlighting infrastructure challenges.

title: Negative Energy Imports
description: In 2022, South Sudan had a net energy import value of -859.50% of energy use, indicating a unique energy export situation.

title: Scarcity of ATMs
description: With only 0.78 ATMs per 100,000 adults in 2021, South Sudan had one of the lowest ATM densities globally.

title: Minimal Bank Borrowers
description: In 2023, only 1.24 out of every 1,000 adults in South Sudan borrowed from commercial banks, reflecting limited financial inclusion.

title: Low Private Sector Credit
description: In 2015, credit to the private sector was just 2.30% of GDP, indicating limited financial support for businesses.

title: Limited Financial Account Ownership
description: As of 2021, only 5.83% of South Sudan's population aged 15+ had an account at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider.

title: Ineffective Government
description: In 2023, South Sudan's government effectiveness estimate was -2.33, indicating significant governance challenges.

title: Low Environmental Sustainability Rating
description: In 2023, South Sudan scored 1 out of 6 in the CPIA policy and institutions for environmental sustainability rating.

title: Poor Budgetary Management
description: South Sudan received a rating of 1 out of 6 for budgetary and financial management in 2023, indicating fiscal challenges.

title: Low Social Protection Rating
description: In 2023, South Sudan's CPIA social protection rating was 1.5, reflecting limited social safety nets.

title: Minimal Revenue Mobilization Efficiency
description: South Sudan scored 2 out of 6 in the CPIA efficiency of revenue mobilization rating in 2023, indicating fiscal inefficiencies.

title: Low Statistical Performance
description: In 2023, South Sudan's overall statistical performance score was 27.51 out of 100, indicating data collection challenges.

title: Negative Import Growth
description: In 2015, South Sudan experienced a -41% growth in imports of goods and services, reflecting economic challenges.

title: Low Primary School Enrollment
description: In 2015, only 35.21% of primary school-age children were enrolled in school, highlighting educational access issues.

title: Minimal Tertiary Education Enrollment
description: In 2018, South Sudan had a tertiary enrollment rate of 1.00% gross, indicating limited higher education access.

title: Low Health Expenditure
description: In 2022, South Sudan's health expenditure per capita was $38.51, reflecting limited investment in healthcare.

title: Minimal Tourism Expenditure
description: In 2020, South Sudan's international tourism expenditures were $1,000,000, indicating a nascent tourism sector.
